To these noted campaigns and campaigners, you can add the hundreds-indeed thousandsof Victorian commuters who have signed the petition, who have sent the Prime Minister a note on the issue, or whose cars sport the 'Fix the jam' sticker. None of them will go away until this issue is resolved. Perhaps more importantly, we have regular metropolitan coverage of this issue in the Herald Sun, which itself is campaigning for this road to be dealt with appropriately and as part of the national highway system. In conclusion, I would like to use the words of the Herald Sun in an editorial that it published late last year about the attitude of this minister and this government to the Geelong road. The tragedy is that, even though we have had a budget come and go in the period since this editorial was published, every word of it remains true today. The editorial read: John Anderson must mend his ways-and Victoria's deadliest road-if he wants to win back support from the bush for the Howard Government. By refusing funds to rebuild the Melbourne-Geelong freeway, the federal Minister for Transport and Regional Services ignores the fact that this narrow, overcrowded 50km stretch of bitumen has claimed 86 lives in the past eight years. Yet Mr Anderson shows callous indifference towards the families of the dead as well as others injured since 1990 in the 6000 crashes on this section of highway. The minister will not explain why his government refuses to provide the $100 million needed to match a similar contribution the Victorian Government would make to fix our worse killer highway. Instead, the people of Geelong and the commuters of Melbourne's outer westnamely, my constituentshave been told by the minister's official spokesman that the Herald Sun's Fix our Deadly Highway campaign is a 'wonderful beat-up in true tabloid fashion'. Some beat-up, some spokesman, some minister, when 86 people are dead. pleased to bring this debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1999-2000 to a conclusion. I have noted that there have been many contributions throughout the course of the several days of debate on this legislation. In fact I am told that 101 speakers have participated in this debate, and that indicates the importance that the parliament places on debate on the national economy and on the management of the national economy by the government. I think it is fair to say that all members expect to see many problems in the Australian community addressed through the appropriation of funds by the Commonwealth, and I indicate that
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Fahey (Macarthur
theText: Minister for Finance and Administration) (9.29 p.m.)-I amMonday, 21 June 1999 MAIN COMMlITEE 6947 perhaps the honourable member for Lalor might fall into that category with her contribution to this debate. Appropriation is a complex process. Roads are a complex process as well. It is simply not a case of saying, 'Let's spend money here, there or anywhere.' It is about ensuring that the spending of public moneys is prioritised correctly and that, where spending occurs, it is within the government's means. We, as a government, have continued to ensure that we do not spend outside our means. That has highlighted and underpinned the administration of the public accounts in the time that the coalition has been in government since 1996. It is also about a government putting together a budget, underpinned by the appropriation bills, which is in accordance with the objectives that the government has set out to achieve, and I would like to touch on those objectives. The 1999-2000 budget builds on our achievements and it addresses our key priorities. Those key priorities are to deliver on our election commitments. I can say that all members of the government were delighted to listen to the Treasurer on election night and to know that, as that budget speech was being delivered and those bills were being tabled, all of those promises put to the Australian people before October of last year were contained, on the first opportunity for such promises to be contained, in a set of bills called the appropriation bills-delivering to the Australian community as promised. The second objective is to promote an economic climate conducive to high levels of sustainable economic and employment growth and to provide a social safety net for those in need. A further priority is to build a modem, fair and efficient taxation system, and the Australian community, heaven knows, needs a modem, a fair and an efficient taxation system. It seems that all Australians acknowledge that, except the Australian Labor Party. Even the Democrats acknowledge that. Another priority is to deliver increased services to rural and regional Australia, and that of course is something which is paramount for the Australian community as a whole. It is a priority for the Liberal Party and the National Party and, as a coalition government, the Liberal and National parties have focused very much on the needs of rural and regional Australia. Lastly, by way of priorities, is the priority of ensuring that government resources are used as effectively and as efficiently as possible. Let me go back to the strong economy. The Labor Party has made much of the social impacts of the budget. Many of those 101 contributions to this debate have continued to address the so-called lack of social impact from those appropriations bills. It seems that Labor continues to take the view that there is a capacity of government to address the social needs. The first role of any government in securing the welfare of its people is to provide sound economic foundations. Far from being mutually exclusive, a government's social and economic goals should support each other. Time and again members will say to you, 'You can afford social policies only when you have the economic side of government in order,' and that is something this government has addressed over its 3Yz years in office. Without those strong economic fundamentals, there can be no guarantee of fulfilling and lasting employment, there can be little hope of security for individuals and families and no stable revenue base to provide the social safety net which all communities demand. These are all reasons why the government acted resolutely to put the budget back into surplus after its election in 1996, why the government moved to put an end to the spiral of 6948 MAIN COMMITTEE Monday, 21 June 1999 deficit and debt left by Labor and not only to bring the budget back into surplus but to keep the budget in surplus. For the third year in a row, the budget will be in surplus, a surplus of more than $5 billion. We have already paid, or repaid, some $24 billion of Labor's debt, and we are now in a position to pay off more debt. In the last four budgets, in net terms, we have not borrowed one single dollar. We are moving steadily towards a debt free Commonwealth, a Commonwealth which was labouring under the burden of some $90 billion of additional debt under the previous Labor government. That was the legacy that Labor left this country in 1996. Sound economic management has protected Australia from the regional economic crisis that many predicted would draw us in. In the face of that regional crisis, our economy continued to grow. In fact, it grew faster than economies in the countries of Europe and faster than economies in the developed world as a whole, even faster than the economy of the USA. And unemployment fell; in the past year 180,000 new jobs were created. The restoration of the fiscal position, along with the government's success in lowering inflation, has provided an environment for the lowest housing interest rates in almost 30 years, and unemployment-which we will acknowledge is still too high-has fallen to its lowest level since the start of the decade. Just as the economic reform of three years ago gave us the strength to ride out the challenges of the last year, the reforms of today will determine how we ride out the challenges of tomorrow. If we want growth, if we want the living standards and jobs in the next decade, we must rise to the challenges of today. The reform of the Australian taxation system is our greatest reform challenge. I will touch on that taxation system, which has been the subject of much debate in the course of dealing with these bills. For Australia's sake we put forward a plan to reform the current outmoded, outdated, complex and unfair taxation system which is holding Australia back. Anyone who is.serious about welfare reform must also be serious about taxation reform. Without a fair and sustainable tax system, the long-term viability of the social safety net must always remain in doubt. Without a broadly based goods and services tax, there can be no guarantee of a secure revenue base for the Australian states and territories to provide the schools, the hospitals, the roads-even, for that matter, roads such as the Geelong road. Without a broad based tax, there can be no guarantee of any roads-or the police. We all know that those things are the needs of the Australian community. Without a broadly based goods and services tax, you cannot abolish 10 unfair taxes including the unfair tax 'bed tax' in the state of New South Wales. You cannot cut personal income taxes. You cannot catch more than the $3 billion that is estimated to be in the black economy, and you cannot reduce the tax on health, education, child care and charitable institutions. The Australian Democrats have recognised this. They have demonstrated a commitment to the national interest by sitting down with the government and working out a way to deliver reform that is in the national interest. Sadly, that once great party, the Australian Labor Party, has vacated centre stage. They have taken a one-way ticket to policy oblivion, and it is has been left to the Democrats to occupy that centre stage in the national interest. This plan will deliver great economic benefits to Australia. What it will deliver is that 80 per cent of Australian taxpayers will be on the top marginal rate of 30 cents in the dollar, and we will be reducing business costs by about $IOYz billion per year. This tax plan will guarantee that no states will be worse off during the transitional period. Further, it guarantees that, after Monday, 21 June 1999 MAIN COMMITTEE 6949 the transitional period, the revenue gains to the states will be such that they will be much better off than if the existing arrangements continue. There are many in this chamber who formerly had a state background and who would know only too well the difficulties that the states faced with the Premiers Conference year after year, wondering what the take would be after the trip to Canberra and knowing always that there was no certainty about whether there would be growth in the revenue of the states, because the Commonwealth had the first say, the Commonwealth had total say, and the states were at the mercy of the Commonwealth when it came to that return of the Australian people's taxes. That will cease. That will cease because there is growth built into the new tax plan, and in the end we are going to have a much better tax system. Let me touch briefly on rural and regional Australia. As I indicated earlier, we are strongly committed to rural and regional Australia and we have delivered a number of important initiatives in this budget. They include a series of measures to improve rural health services in the short and the long term, measures to ensure that students from rural and regional areas have much better access to education, and measures to defeat the distances that make it hard for rural and regional Australia to access government and community services, through the establishment of the regional transaction centres. In the area of education we will spend some $4.8 billion on primary and secondary school children in government and non-government schools. We are committed to the provision of choice in education, again for the benefit of all Australians. And whilst many speakers have addressed this issue, I have noted with some interest that there has been some conjecture about the contribution to non-government schools. The contribution which the government stands firmly behind and is very proud of will bring an additional $553 million over five years to the Catholic systemic schools, and that implements once again an election commitment made last October. This decision came out of an independent assessment of the needs of the system which was conducted by the Non-Government Schools Funding Review Committee. The budget announced a new formula for distributing recurrent funding to non-government schools based on the needs of the parents and taking into account the resources of the community that a school serves. In 200 I, non-government schools will be funded according to a measure of the socioeconomic status, known as the SES, of their school communities. The new funding arrangements replace a system that was widely seen as unfair. It was complex. and it was inadequate as a measure of need. We are going to have a much better and a fairer education funding system. Government schools have not been neglected. In the five years ahead an additional $1 billion has been provided for government schools. I referred in the priorities of government to effective and efficient government and the need to ensure that all that a government does achieves those objectives. Our public finances are reported and presented on a world class basis. Our Charter of Budget Honesty is now advocated internationally as a model for other countries. This budget represents a major shift in the way the federal government budgets for and manages its resources because for the first time the Commonwealth based its budget on outcomes and outputs and accrual accounting principles. But this entails much more than a technical change in accounting policies. The new framework puts outcomes and outputs-that is, results and deliverables-at the centre of how agencies plan, how they budget, how they 6950 MAIN COMMITTEE Monday, 21 June 1999 manage and how they report. It marks a strategic and more business like approach and it incorporates standard financial statements with a strong emphasis on results. After all, surely that is what it is about. It is about outcomes, it is not about process. Traditional cash budgeting makes it difficult to assess the financial position of agencies or to compare performance from one financial year to another. It simply does not promote best practice management by agencies or true accountability. Accrual budgeting is recognised internationally as a more accurate tool. It is based on full costs as they are incurred. It changes both how and what is measured for budgeting, for accounting, and for reporting purposes. All in all, it means government having a better handle on knowing precisely how much it costs agencies to do business. The critical element is changing the performance focus to budgeting, managing and reporting on the outputs and the full costs required to achieve the outcomes that the government wants. The object is clarity: it is clear accountability; consistently applied and clear performance measures; realistic goods and services, planned and delivered; and, ultimately, the financial results that are achieved. The result is more transparent, and more transparent government is in fact something all of us would seek to achieve. The move makes Australia a world leader in government budgeting practices and positions Australia at the forefront of the international community for public sector resource management. The Labor Party has suggested that the move to accrual budgeting is an important change, but not important enough to mark as a major achievement of this budget. In one sense, and one sense only, this is true. Accrual budgeting is a tool to achieve the real end of an efficient and effective public sector, one that achieves the outcomes government wants, at the lowest possible cost. This allows the government to direct its resources to the areas of highest needs. The strong economic foundations which we have built, and continue to build upon, are the best guarantee of employment growth, security for individuals and families, and a stable revenue base to provide that social safety net I referred to earlier that the community demands. I thank all members for their contribution and I commend the bills to the House. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. Consideration in Detail the bill in detail. In accordance with standing order 226, the committee will first consider the schedule of the bill. that it might suit the convenience of the Main Committee to consider the items of proposed expenditure in the order and groupings shown in the schedule which has been circulated to honourable members. The consideration of the items in groups of departments has met the convenience of the House and the Main Committee in past years. I also take the opportunity to indicate to the Main Committee that the proposed order for consideration of departments' estimates has been discussed with the opposition and the Independent member and there has been no objection to what is proposed. The schedule read as follows-

speaker: Mr Deputy Speaker (Hon. D.h. Adams)
theText: The Main Committee will now consider
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Fahey (Macarthur
theText: Minister for Finance and Administration) (9.47 p.m.)-I su-estMonday, 21 June 1999 MAIN COMMITTEE 6951 Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry] Together Department of the Environment and Heritage Department of Transport and Regional Services Attorney-General's Department Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts Department of Defence] Department of Veterans' Affairs Together Department of Industry, Science and Resources Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet Department of the Treasury] Together Department of Finance and Administration Department of Family and Community Services Department of Health and Aged Care Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs proposed expenditure in the order suggested by the minister? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed. Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry Proposed expenditure $394,718,000. Department of the Environment and Heritage Proposed expenditure $593,270,000. Mr O'CONNOR (Corio) (9.49 p.m.)-I welcome the opportunity in this consideration in detail stage to make some more detailed comments on the appropriations which comprise the government's outlays in the Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry portfolio area. I propose to engage this debate on two levels. One is to comment on the fundamental assumptions which underlie the outlays which have been made in this portfolio area and, indeed, the government's overall budget strategy; and then to make some more specific comments on some of the programs that have been funded in this particular portfolio area. I was very interested in the comments of the Minister for Finance and Administration who preceded me in the general debate on Appropriation Bill (No.1) 1999-2000. He made some comment on the broad objectives that the government is pursuing in this budget strategy, and I presume those objectives relate in some way to the Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry portfolio. The first objective he stated was that the government was delivering on its election commitments. I am sure that the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry will get up and tell the House just how wonderful the government has been in addressing some of the promises that it made in the context of election campaigns. But I say, 'About time.' You spent three years driving the boot into the bush. You spent the last three years stripping away the services to rural and regional Australia. We would expect you, in this budget, at least
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Deputy Speaker
theText: Is it the wish of the Main Committee to consider the items of6952 MAIN COMMITTEE Monday, 21 June 1999 with the $5.5 billion surplus, to start addressing some of the damage that you caused in the previous three budgets that you brought down. It was a comprehensive betrayal. What the government has attempted to do in this budget after it has stripped the homestead bare over three years is to refurbish the one room bungalow out the back. If you think that is really going to restore your credibility in rural and regional Australia, you have another think coming because I am going to reflect, in the context of this debate, on some of the programs that you are funding and what the rural sector has said about them. The finance minister commented on the importance of developing a sustainable economic climate for growth and employment. We are happy to engage you on that particular debate. We left you with an inflation rate of less than two per cent and a growth rate in excess of four per cent. I do not know why the minister for agriculture here acquiesced to a Liberal lawyer who masquerades as an economic expert, why a member of the National Party would roll over year after year after year to drive the economy backwards so that it can go forwards. It is back to the future so that we can progress. That is what we had in the three years preceding this particular budget. One of the objectives of a finance minister is to build a modem, fair and efficient taxation system. If you think the package that you have delivered with the Democrats is really going to be accepted in the bush by those farm businesses that you are going to now heap on millions of dollars worth of compliance costs, and if you think that is going to restore some credibility out there in the bush, I think you are really barking up another tree. The king of all statements was what the finance minister said this budget was about: increasing the level of services to rural and regional Australia. As I said, you spent three years stripping the rural sector bare of those services, so we would hope that, in one of your budgets in four years, you might address some of the damage that you have done. It is interesting that the finance minister talks about bringing the budget back into surplus and the importance of wiping out deficits and running budget surpluses. We agree with you on that. We do not have a problem with that because we think the rural sector needs, consistently over time, a secure fundamental macro-economic framework in which it can develop and grow. The minister for agriculture is smiling away and he is going to trumpet the achievements of the government which, in effect, were the achievements of Labor in government that he is now attempting to claim as his own. (Extension of time granted) I found these comments about the surplus quite extraordinary. In the postwar era, we had 22 years of Liberal deficits and Liberal debt. In the Fraser years, when the current Prime Minister had control of the treasury bench, we had another seven years of Liberal coalition deficits. So we know a bit about deficits. We know about coalition deficits because we had something like 29 years in our post World War II experience of coalition deficits. We had the onerous task of bringing the Commonwealth budget back into surplus, which we did on four occasions. The former minister for agriculture grins away. Four Labor surpluses, 29 years of coalition deficit-I think there is a bit of an imbalance there. We would expect you to run a surplus. We would expect you to emulate what we gave you-growth, a high-growth economy, a low-inflation economy and, of course, budget surpluses. I have got to say to the minister that we welcome the fact that we have flushed out of the system the 29 years of coalition deficits and that you have now joined us in producing budget surpluses. We are happy to do that. But, of course, I find it quite extraordinary that the finance minister said, and I think I got the quote correct: Monday, 21 June 1999 MAIN COMMITTEE 6953 ... the reforms of today will determine how we ride out the challenges of tomorrow. That is a very good quote because that is what we did in 13 years when we had to reform the Australian economy and Australia's agricultural sector to put it on a sound financial footing so that it could weather the economic crisis that the finance minister referred to. We had to massively restructure our industrial base. Labor engaged in the most comprehensive program of micro-economic reform that this country has ever seen. We developed a true export culture in our manufacturing and agricultural industries. We reformed the finance system. Labor engaged in skill development, infrastructure development and investment development as contained in the programs of One Nation, Working Nation and Investing in the Nation, and indeed the reforms over those 13 years positioned Australia to ride out the challenges that the finance minister referred to in the debate today. An important feature of this consideration in detail stage is the opportunity that it presents to reflect on the government's budget in the cool light of day and against the backdrop of some of the comments by those affected in the government's announced decisions. The role of the opposition is certainly not a spoiling role. We are not here to disagree with every initiative mounted by the government in the budget context. Indeed, .it would be strange if a government of any particular persuasion were to go through the budget process, with the enormous creative resources of an expert department at their disposal, and not come up with worthwhile initiatives. I do not propose here tonight to take issue with all elements of the government's rural budget. There are some initiatives in there that we as an opposition would support. Indeed we might take the view that the government has perhaps not gone far enough in its funding allocation to meet the particular problems facing the rural sector at this point of time. The $30 million over five years to rehabilitate the Great Artesian Basin is one initiative we would support. The $4.2 million national ovine Johne's disease control program is another. The $15.8 million over four years to increase patrols in our sub-Antarctic waters to protect our fisheries is another expenditure that we would support. From the opposition's point of view, we question some of the fundamental assumptions on which this budget and many of the programs targeted at the rural sector are indeed based. We have to appreciate the political context in which this budget was brought down. It was brought down against the backdrop of three years in which the coalition has taken a real belting out in rural and regional Australia. We take the view that this inot the real budget and, as I have said, we have questioned its underlying assumptions and its lack of vision. (Extension of time granted) I would like to make some quotes about the fundamental assumptions that the government has based its rural budget on and indeed about its lack of vision. In relation to the underlyingr assumptions, in The Land, Peter Austin had an article headlined 'How thin is budget ice' and he had this to say about it: The real worry in the budget is the extent to which outcomes rely on factors well beyond the government's control-and I don't simply refer to the sale of the rest of Telstra.... The thing underpinning our projected high levels of growth is consumer spending, which could fall in a hole overnight ... a consumer spending boom is no way to sustain an economy, especially when so much of the wealth is derived from unproductive activity .... Like Simon Crean, I wonder why the government is so keen to ditch a tax system that has so far succeeded in keeping Australia on the path of low inflation and strong growth during a period of regional turmoil in favour of something untried and problem fraught. 6954 MAIN COMMITTEE Monday, 21 June 1999 Those are not our concerns that are raised; those are the concerns of rural commentators. I go to a quote by an Alectown farmer, Peter Unger, in The Land of 13 May, where he refers to one of the fundamental assumptions on which the government's revenue projections are based. He had this to say: I expected better of Peter Costello and Tim Fischer. [... ] Tim Fischer-supposedly battling for the rural sector-is out again for another 'duck' ... selling Telstra to achieve its budget surplus-it's just creative accounting. I could just as easily thrill my bank manager by selling the front paddock ... In effect, what we are doing here is selling a future revenue stream from an institution and an economic enterprise that farmers already own. They already own it; they already have a share in it, and you want to sell it to foreigners. That is how they perceive it out there in the bush and they are right on to you guys-the National Party-in rural Australia. If there is one element of the betrayal or one broken promise that will be a millstone around your neck-and we will make sure it is-it is the sale of Telstra. You promised you would not sell it and then you said you would not run it down. been pleased to see me, but nonetheless he will still direct his remarks through the chair, or he will be less pleased. Mr O'CONNOR-I will do that; I am humbled before your ruling. IfI might just comment on the lack of vision in the budget, I think there are some very telling quotes that I can read to this House about what the farm sector had to say about the budget's lack of vision. The United Graziers Association of Queensland stated: ... the budget was fiscally responsible but innocuous and neutral, lacking in initiatives to spark wealth creation for the nation in the longer term. They were referring there to one of the great wealth creating sectors of this nation-the agricultural sector. The UGA President, Noel Kennedy, had this to say in the discussions that I had with him: A debt free Australia was a noble aim but he would have preferred to see the $S.2B surplus put into infrastructure development. The Queensland Farmers Federation said that the budget contained some useful and welcome measures-we agree with that; we do not have a problem with that-but 'lacked a clear and coherent vision for the rural sector'. Here are farming groups saying of the government-after three years with their hands on the tiller, having stripped rural and regional Australia bare and driven the boot into the bush-' All they can come up with is a budget that lacks vision.' I would like to address in my concluding remarks the issue of services and the equity of access for rural people to services. The NFF has been quite critical of the previous budgets of the government in this respect. Ian Donges, the NFF President, in a press release of 11 May, stated: The NFF remains concerned that the Government's spending proposals will not sufficiently redress the inequities between city and country Australians. The NFF is disappointed in the reduction in funding for Co-operative Research Centres, which have the capacity to contribute enormously to providing Australia with the scientific edge. . . .. there is a long way to go before rural and regional Australians will feel they're getting the same level of services as those who live in the cities.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Deputy Speaker ( Mr Nehl)
theText: Order! The honourable member for Corio might haveMonday, 21 June 1999 MAIN COMMITIEE 6955 It is a very neutral comment which really sums up the attitude of many rural and .regional Australians who are disappointed with the government's performance in this budget. There are specifics of the budget that I would like.to deal with, but I think I am going to run out of time. We certainly have some serious questions about elements of the budget: the departmental cutbacks, the initiatives in biotechnology, Supermarket to Asia and the educational initiatives. (Time expired) forestry in the 1999 budget is a one-off allocation of $5.8 million to complete the eight remaining regional forest agreements. Of this figure, $4 million goes to the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and $1.8 million to the Department of the Environment and Heritage. As Labor initiated the RFA process and remains strongly committed to it, we agree that adequateÂ· funding must be provided to allow the necessary economic, social and environmental assessments to be completed by the December guideline. This does not mean, of course, that we agree with the approach being taken by the Minister for Forestry and Conservation. In his home state of Western Australia, we see clear signs that the RFA he signed last month is already unravelling in a massive way. In the last week, we have seen a National Party MP cross the floor in the state parliament on the issue. The state director of the Western Australian National Party, a close friend of those opposite, has warned of dire electoral consequences. It is indicated in today's West Australian that there is a strong push from within the coalition with five Liberal Party backbenchers pressing for a review of which forest blocks are to be protected in the reserve system. As noted in my media release earlier today, the Western Australian RFA can hardly be seen as a secure 20-year agreement for the future when the state's Deputy Premier and leader of the National Party publicly talks about possible changes only a month after it was signed. These developments reinforce my view that the ham-fisted approach taken by Minister Tuckey will ultimately prove to be counterproductive for the very industry groups that he purports to be protecting. The budget also continues funding for two other of Labor's forest initiatives: the Forest Industry Structural Adjustment Program-FISAP; and the Wood and Paper Industry Strategy-WAPIS. I will briefly touch on each of these vital programs. Labor introduced the FISAP program in 1995 to help the native forest industry adjust t() the requirements of Labor's national forest policy statement of 1992. It was always clear that this statement would lead to significant reductions of timber harvesting to more sustainable levels and to a significant expansion in the size of the reserve system for old-growth forest. . All of the early, misleading rhetoric from the current federal minister-later discounted and dismissed by the Western Australian state government-that there would be no job losses is exactly what that program was aimed at. Labor allocated $107 million of Commonwealth funds over five years to FISAP and secured significant matching funding from the New South Wales state Labor government. Despite the government's rhetoric about looking after timber workers, one of the first things the current coalition government did after the 1996 election was to cut $6 million from FISAP. More recently, in November last year, the minister unilaterally suspended FISAP funding to New South Wales in a clear attempt to stand over the Carr government. The irony of this move is that, of the states, New South Wales alone has contributed significant amounts of state funding to FISAP. According to the Commonwealth's own figures, as of last February, New South Wales has provided $15 million. No other state
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Laurie Ferguson (Reid) (10.05 P.m.)
theText: The sole new funding allocation for6956 MAIN COMMITTEE Monday, 21 June 1999 has provided a single cent to FISAP, yet New South Wales is the only state whose funding has been suspended. Now that the New South Wales election is over, and with the coalition, predictably, suffering a devastating loss, it is clearly time for the Commonwealth to restore FISAP funding. In recent Senate estimates hearings, Commonwealth officials said that negotiations about this were continuing but refused to promise that New South Wales would have its original allocation completely restored. I invite the minister to stop using timber workers as the meat in the sandwich in Commonwealth-state negotiations and restore FISAP funding to New South Wales without further delay. The coalition's approach to Labor's Wood and Paper Industry Strategy has been equally deplorable and lacking. Indeed, one of the first decisions it made was to abolish the expert Wood and Paper Industry Council that was supposed to drive strategy. Such an industry council obviously did not fit comfortably with the anti-interventionist approach of its key economic ministers. It is all right for Minister Tuckey to say that he is a good bloke and a friend of the CFMEU, but he really cannot get past Prime Minister Howard because Prime Minister Howard is so strongly against this kind of industry policy. In place of the council the former industry minister set up-but not until 18 months had passed-a Wood and Paper Industry Forum, which has met twice. This great industry council, which is going to drive industry policy, has met twice in the period of the coalition government. The lack of seriousness with which the coalition approaches the industry strategy is demonstrated by this fact. (Extension of time granted) It is little wonder that the current minister, having essentially dismissed the performance of Minister Moore and his other predecessors in this policy field, has taken to reconvening a series of meetings with industry stakeholders to develop what he calls 'an action agenda' for the timber industry? This is something that the opposition will be paying close attention to. So far the minister has been strong on rhetoric and short on action. He has refused to commit the government to re-establish the Wood and Paper Industry Council, telling the union that if he is forced with a gun at his head to adopt this council he will, because he really cannot get it across to Prime Minister Howard that it is a good idea; he is really a nice guy, a friend of the union, but Prime Minister Howard is stopping this type of policy direction. Let us say to the minister: your rhetoric might be more attuned than your predecessor's to the need for an industry policy, but we will be watching for outcomes-whether you will re-establish the Wood and Paper Industry Council and give it sufficient resources to do its job; what your promised action agenda provides for in terms of specific industry development and research measures; and, most of all, how much in funding the Commonwealth will provide with a strategy for the three to five financial years after the budget we are currently discussing. All of these questions must of course be viewed in the context of the manner in which the government, soon after its election, attacked the Wood and Paper Industry Council, attacked where all the stakeholders were involved in a very real sense. Debate (on motion by Mr Zahra) adjourned.
